title: 106_hr4503
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as historically women's public college or university, historic building or structure, and Secretary. SEC. 3. Preservation and restoration grants for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary shall award grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings on their campuses. Grants will be funded through appropriations for the National Historic Preservation Act. Grantees must agree not to alter the property without the Secretary's approval for a specified period. The Secretary may award grants for preserving historic buildings at women's public colleges or universities. Grantees must allow public access for interpretive and educational purposes. Funds for buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places require a 50% match from non-Federal sources. Funding provisions state that up to $16,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005 can be allocated for grants under the program. In-kind contributions from non-Federal interests can be used for the non-Federal share of costs. Funding provisions allocate $2,000,000 each to various universities including Mississippi University for Women, Georgia College and State University, University of North Carolina, Winthrop University, University of Montevallo, Texas Woman's University, University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma, and Wesleyan College. If less than $16,000,000 is available, adjustments will be made. If less than $16,000,000 is available, funding to universities listed in the previous paragraph will be reduced. Funds for fiscal years 2002-2005 will be distributed to eligible grantees on a uniform basis. The Secretary will create necessary regulations to implement this Act. Passed the House of Representatives on October 3, 2000. Clerk attested.
